title.narrative: 7.6 COMMUNICATION FOR DEVELOPMENT

description.narrative: UNICEF, the Government and partners are capable of developing the capacities of women, girls, boys and communities to lead and actively participate oin their own development, including during shocks and stresses, by adopting essential family behaviours and practices and enhancing local and community-managed services, which contributes to Cross-Sectoral Communication For Development, Cross-Sectoral Communication For Development (Covid), Operations Support To Programme Delivery. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, United Nations Working Together. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: UNICEF, the Government and partners adopt improved practices for effectively planning, implementing and monitoring programmes and delivering quality, multi-sectoral and equity focused resuls

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: UNICEF, the Government and partners are capable of developing the capacities of women, girls, boys and communities to lead andactively participate oin their own development, including during shocks and stresses, by adopting essential family behaviours andpractices and enhancing local and community-managed services

description.narrative: COVID-19 and other preventable disease-related messaging was communicated using a mix of communication channels like radio, social mobilisers, opinion leaders and social media.; The resulting 91% - 96% awareness and community engagement, reduced COVID-19 and other disease outbreak related infection and fatalities. UNICEF provided crucial leadership to the RCCE pillar as well as to the RCCE taskforce, built capacity on social and behaviour change communication in government organisations, pillar members, implementing partners and frontline workers, institutionalised the use of Open Data Kit (ODKs), and provided supportive supervision through yearlong initiatives. | Status:Met | As-of Date:11/01/2021
